thread.title: Tory David Davis confronted with German newspaper Die Welt's brutal verdict on Theresa May's Brexit speech
thread.title_full: Tory David Davis confronted with German newspaper Die Welt's brutal verdict on Theresa May's Brexit speech

author: Dan Bloom
title: Tory David Davis confronted with German newspaper Die Welt's brutal verdict on Theresa May's Brexit speech
text:
News Tory David Davis confronted with German newspaper Die Welt's brutal verdict on Theresa May's Brexit speech Despite being shown the hostile reaction from Europe on live TV, the Brexit Secretary claimed: "I think it’s gone down incredibly well" Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now David Davis confronted with German newspaper's brutal Brexit message Share this video Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
One of Germany's top newspapers has led a brutal European reaction to Theresa May's Brexit speech. 
The front page of Die Welt features the Union Jack-surrounded Prime Minister branded with the logo of BBC comedy Little Britain. 
Brexit Secretary David Davis was confronted with the front page on live TV this morning as he tried to deny Britain wants to "have its cake and eat it". 
The PM has said Britain will leave full membership of the single market and customs union - and walk away without a deal if it's not good enough. Read More 
That led Spanish newspaper ABC to warn "May threatens the EU with a commercial war". Italian daily La Repubblica wrote "London gets its wall" and Czech daily Dnes had an unflattering photo of the PM headlined "no compromise". 
Yet despite the hostile reaction Mr Davis claimed: "I think it’s gone down incredibly well." 
In a round of interviews this morning, Sky News presenter Sarah-Jane Mee compared the front page to the Daily Mail, whose headline was "steel of the new iron lady". 
And she questioned him on the headline in The Times, which portrayed Mrs May's warning as "give us a fair deal or you'll be crushed". 
Mr Davis replied: "That’s The Times, that’s not the Prime Minister." Read More Tory Brexit Secretary David Davis reveals he made £1,000 betting on Leave 
He clashed with the presenter over his plan to steamroller ahead with Brexit even if MPs vote his "tough negotiation" down. 
He claimed losing a final vote in Parliament in 2019 was "utterly hypothetical" and "I intend to win it". David Davis on Sky News (Photo: Sky News) 
But questioned on what he'd do if he does lose, he told ITV's Good Morning Britain: "We will leave anyway." 
He even boldly claimed: "It won’t go wrong. We’re very clear what we’re going to do, we’re very clear what we want out of this and it’s in everybody’s interests. 
"Why on earth can it go wrong?" 
Mr Davis said ministers "want a tariff-free deal" with the EU single market, a key demand of Labour. 
And asked if Brits' holidays in the EU would be affected, he claimed: "You won’t see any difference let’s say in the right to travel." 
But he did not rule out his "phased" transition taking five years after the Brexit deadline of March 2019. David Davis on Good Morning Britain (Photo: ITV) 
Asked if it would stretch beyond the 2020 general election he said: "I could imagine that". 
He admitted lorries could face customs checks, saying: "We'll see, that's one of the things we want to negotiate." 
He said the idea of Scotland staying in the single market was "technically difficult" and "would not be accepted". 
And asked how much Britain would carry on paying into the EU, he told LBC: "I'm not going to answer a question like that". (Photo: Getty) Theresa May warned Britain could leave without a deal in her long-awaited speech (Photo: REUTERS) 
Tomas Prouza, the Czech Republic's secretary of state for EU affairs, said the Prime Minister's speech should have had more for the EU. 
He told the BBC: "We expected at least some formal assurances as part of that speech and there was nothing in there." 
He welcomed the PM's "positive" approach but said: "If the result is more nationalism more xenophobia and trying to whip up these nationalistic sentiments im very worried." 
He claimed after studying 20 years of records he's never seen so many attacks on EU citizens in the UK. May spoke to Merkel and Hollande last night. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
